Entries.default:
A fire godlike woman polishes a pair of stocks, tending to them with the fondness of a mother for her favorite child.

The room is dim, illuminated only by the glow of her steel-forged skin. Her eyes burn with the light of Magran's fire.
"You are a glutton for punishment, I see."
"I will give you an experience you won't soon forget."
"How much for your time?"
"Three hundred copper. I know it's a bit more than most, but my service is like nothing you will find anywhere else in Neketaka."
"Tell me about yourself."

"I must assume the question beneath your question is how a fire godlike came to find herself in a place such as this."

She leans back against a wall of chains. They clank and rattle, and she smiles at the sound.
"Never mind."
"Very well. Remove your clothing and shut the door." She runs a hand along her freshly polished stocks while she waits for you to comply with her orders.
"Let's get to it, then."

"But we cannot always be strong. I help those who have lost their strength to find it again."

She wraps a chain around her arm and tugs. The steel links glow red with forge-fire where they touch her skin.

"Perseverance. Being as I am, I have been forced to find it for myself. Now, I teach it to others.

"To live in the world as a thinking, feeling creature - it is difficult. It demands strength."
"Tekēhu! Where have you been? I haven't seen you in weeks." Her eyes glow red with an intense, flickering flame, but her tone is warm and familiar.

"Still recovering after the last visit, I say! My mind is willing, but my scales have limits." 

Tekēhu rubs the back of his head and smiles.
"Oh yes, we are well acquainted. He's a very good boy." She smirks.
"You know her?"
[Say nothing.]
"Ekera, we have... quenched each other's flames from time to time."
"You may leave."
"You want to speak with me, you do it in my room."
"Start slowly, please." Tekēhu pinches his lower lip and smiles.
"You have my undivided attention." Maia folds her arms and observes, smiling lopsidedly.
"Hold on just one murkberry-picking minute! I don't know if you know this about me, Watcher, but I ain't the kind of gal who likes to share."

She turns away to polish a pair of stocks, tending to them with the fondness of a mother for her favorite child.

The room is dim, illuminated only by the glow of her steel-forged skin. Her eyes burn with the light of Magran's fire.
When she realizes you're still standing there, she shoots you a look of utter contempt.
When she hears you enter, she shoots you a look of utter contempt.
